resources.string: Arithmetic is a branch of mathematics that involves numbers and basic operations like addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division. It is the foundation of all math concepts.

Greek philosopher and mathematician, known for the theorem named after him. In arithmetic, he explored the properties of numbers, such as perfect numbers, amicable numbers, and figurate numbers (triangular, square, etc.). He founded the Pythagorean school, which viewed numbers as the foundation of the universe.

Author of The Elements, a foundational work in mathematics. In arithmetic, he developed the Euclidean algorithm to find the greatest common divisor (GCD) and worked on the theory of prime numbers, proving that there are infinitely many primes.
Known as the "father of algebra," he wrote Arithmetica, a treatise on equations and integers. He introduced solutions to Diophantine equations, which seek integer solutions to arithmetic problems.

Indian mathematician who worked in arithmetic and astronomy. He introduced the decimal numbering system with the use of zero and developed methods for solving quadratic equations and calculating square roots.

Persian mathematician whose name gave rise to the word "algorithm." In his work Al-Kitab al-Mukhtasar fi Hisab al-Jabr wal-Muqabala, he systematized arithmetic operations and popularized the use of Hindu-Arabic numerals in the West.
Introduced the Hindu-Arabic numeral system to Europe with his book Liber Abaci. He is also famous for the Fibonacci sequence, an arithmetic series with applications in nature and mathematics.
